data: PED RESP NIPPV/CPAP/High Flow for Stable Patients on Inpatient Medical Wards (Module)
Respirology to follow patients requiring Non-Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NIPPV) or Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) on medical inpatient units
Refer to NIPPV Management on Inpatient Units
Refer to High Flow Nasal Cannula in Bronchiolitis (< 1 year) Guideline for patients with bronchiolitis
q3h, Respiratory Therapist to perform site to source safety checks q3h
q6h, Monitor skin on face for breakdown each time NIPPV/CPAP mask is removed and at a minimum of q6h. Increase frequency as needed
q4h, Vital signs include respiratory rate, heart rate, pulse oximetry, blood pressure, temperature and pain assessment. To be completed with PEWS assessment
Continuous cardiorespiratory monitoring when patient is on NIPPV/CPAP/High Flow
Notify Treating Provider if vital signs not within normal parameters
Vent G Tube before initiating NIPPV, q4h and PRN
No oral or bolus feeding one hour before NIPPV/CPAP
NIPPV/CPAP/High Flow may be initiated and managed by a Respiratory Therapist on the inpatient wards for patients that are clinically stable
NIPPV/CPAP/High Flow may be initiated and delivered to patients that are considered to be clinically stable
NIPPV/CPAP/High Flow is NOT to be used for escalation of care on the inpatient wards
Trained staff, caregivers and family members may apply and remove NIPPV/CPAP
Reason for Consult: NIPPV, Set up NIPPV/CPAP/High Flow and validate settings as per physician orders
If ordering High Flow for bronchiolitis, refer to High Flow Nasal Cannula in Bronchiolitis (< 1 year) Guideline
Titrate O2 to keep SpO2 92% or greater
Titrate O2 to keep SpO2 94% or greater
Nurses can titrate FiO2 from 0.21 to a maximum of 0.4 to maintain saturations as ordered. Contact RT if requiring more than FiO2 of 0.4
When ordering NIPPV, complete EPAP, IPAP, I-Time, Back Up Rate, Mode +/- Pressure Support
